poem:
"Skimming Wyllie's Whimsical Waters"

George Wyllie, a sculptor, ingenious and spry,  
Turning the Clyde into his own laughter-sky.  
Paper boats, flaming engines, question marks of steel,  
Jumbled up, deep critiques concealed.  
Oh, the mirth-veiled dissent, against machine and nature's feud,  
Wyllie's art, trinkets of truths, in quietude.  
his legacy, a curious museum along the waterside,  
Carving chuckles out of the smothering industrial tide.
